author: walden
title: Artifact- Real Estate Utility Token
description: 房地产交易的效率很低，买卖双方都缺乏效率和透明度。

f6_assessments.q0: Any proposal that portends to upset and major market without a serious component of HOW they will accomplish this massive change (not what the change is) lacks the potential for success
f6_assessments.q1: Feasibility depends not just on the idea, but more so the implemenation. This proposal says what they hope to accomplish - whilst completely avoiding a cogent discussion of how they will accomplish that makes sea change
f6_assessments.q2: This proposal offers a white paper in 3 months. OK, they can do that. But what will be the quality of that white paper. Suggest they go invest the time and energy, produce the whitepaper, then return for funding. Plus no discussion about who will produce the dev work. Nor how the $20k will be spent.

f6_assessments.q0: I really love this bit: "This product will increase transaction efficiency and transparency by using blockchain technology to verify and update financial due diligence in real time all without breaching personal privacy of the buyer." - This aligns very nicely with the goals of ATALA prism and the idea that would should be able to verify and interact with other people with a high degree of trust and verifiability while at the same time still maintaining our anonymity. This fits perfectly with the theme of Cardano's ethos put forth by Charles.
f6_assessments.q1: The team includes a Plutus Pioneer and a real estate investor with escrow experience. I do believe that the team has enough experience and know-how to successfully implement the solution they are proposing in this proposal. The only question mark for me is how the market responses which nobody can answer and so ultimately I cannot give this proposal five stars.
f6_assessments.q2: Roadmap is fantastic and the milestones are detailed and KPIs are specific. I think this proposal will actually be very easy to audit using the KPIs provided i.e. escrow tokens minted, deals signed, backend finished etc. and don't believe I can say much more about it.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal describes a solution for dealing with real estate purchases where a buyer will need to send funds as a form of deposit on the property. When this occurs there is a need for funds to be stored in escrow whilst also being compliant with regulation. This situation is a good example of a high value situation where mistakes such as scams which were mentioned in the proposal can be very costly. These factors make blockchain an effective solution to prevent these problems listed which means this proposal potentially having a large impact in this market. The proposal team has not provided and sources of references that help provide further evidence to the proposal information which would be needed to give this a higher rating.
f6_assessments.q1: Four team members are listed with basic information on their backgrounds. No sources or linked are given to provide evidence that the team members have the experience mentioned. A budget break down is not provided, the budget requested is reasonable but unclear on how it is used. Some of the team members are closely involved in Gimbalabs where there is more evidence of the skill and ability of some of the team members. Blake McNeal appears to be the main connection with the real estate market and as such would be very beneficial to have more information on their background and links towards their involvement in the space. The feasibility of this proposal is based upon the strength of these connections and the likelihood the proposal team can persuade a company working in real estate to trial their solution.
f6_assessments.q2: Details description and milestones are provided for each key component of the proposal. Some of the milestones seem to be very forward looking and as a result feel fairly ambitious without first trialling the solution in a single company setting. A KPI of getting a few companies onboard feels like it would suffice to prove the impact of the solution. The clarity of the proposal could have also been more refined. As an example read the conclusion of the proposal - it is a 6 line single sentence!

f6_assessments.q0: The Proposal provides a solution to a very big market that has become a favourite target of criminals, who can easily steal large amounts of cash. With this proposal the team aims to create Artifact "Funding" Tokens that can be used to serve as payment between the seller and buyer.
f6_assessments.q1: The Team mentioned, are given in short with a short mention of their skills. No links are provided for proof or to verify. The budget is not broken down at all. There is a detailed plan, and how the whole process will work is described in a very good detailed manner. There is also a bit of a timeline. From this proposal I can see the proposers know exactly how they see it happens, and the process it needs to follow. Its a pity they did not spend a little more time on the breaking down of the budget etc. Risk are also not discussed.
f6_assessments.q2: There is not any given method given of how the community can track the progress. We will only possibly see the end result. They should Ideally mention that they will be giving feedback, and how often and through which channels, so the voters and community members can see how the project is progressing. I hope this does eventually get voted in.

f6_assessments.q0:
This proposal tries to tackle a common problems, but the proposed solution seems very convoluted and impractical. Real state buyers are usually so only one-time, or years apart. Therefore, the need of having to go through a qualifying process seems to be an inconvenience. 
The case for sellers is not clear to me, as I'm not familiar with the US real state legislation, and I gather proving ownership might be way more complicated than what I'm used to. I'll consider this to be necessary and impactful. 

The proposal seems to be a centralized solution, as the issuance of tokens is done by the proposer company. DeFi should be about trustless transactions, but in this case, it seems trust just shifts from an entity to another. 

There might be potential on using DiDs for the buyer/seller qualification phase (and submitting to a different challenge), but according to the description, that's not part of the plan. In fact, they might be "reinventing the wheel", according to the following sentence: "Artifact [...] encrypt Buyer data [...] and issues [...] Token that serves as a real time "green light" indicating a qualified state". This token sounds a lot like a credential from a decentralized identity platform, but done in a proprietary and not interoperable way. This is a big red flag for me.
f6_assessments.q1: Team profiles are just job titles (I'd expect fuller profiles), but they declare to have skills mainly in software development, and the proposal also includes very aggressive business development, across 50 states, and even internationally. The proposer states to have established "relationship" with a large company, that might provide the necessary scale for a big part of this.
f6_assessments.q2: Clear and quantifiable milestones are provided. However, one of the first milestones is "Voters elect to successfully fund Artifact from catalyst fund 6", and the Fund6 proposal was not funded. It seems the proposer was planning on building on work from the Fund6, and this proposal was not updated after not being funded. Does this compromise the whole project?

solution: 将融资尽职调查编码为 "资金 "代币；将不动产记录/权利编码为 "托管 "代币。
experience:
团队。
15年以上的软件开发经验，plutus先锋，5年的房地产投资、经纪和代管经验
